Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Distributed coordination of smart devices to mitigate intermittency of renewable generation for a smarter and sustainable power grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ultimate goal of the project is to help the electric grid become more reliable even when a large amount of electricity is generated from green, but intermittent - sources such as solar and wind. To deal with this intermittency, inexpensive source of energy storage are required. Instead of investing in batteries, this project seeks to obtain cheap storage by manipulating power demand in consumer loads through intelligent decision-making algorithms. By varying power demand up and down from what a load would nominally consume, the load can be made to behave like a battery, effectively creating a source of Virtual Energy Storage (VES). This kind of virtual storage is cheaper than batteries since it is a software-based solution; little additional hardware is needed. Another aspect of the project is to develop decision-making algorithms to cope with operational issues faced by the power distribution networks (that deliver electricity to neighborhoods) due to increasing use of intermittent solar power.

There are several technical challenges in achieving this vision: of intelligently manipulating consumer loads and other devices to help the power grid operate reliably. This project aims to address two of these key challenges. One is the design of algorithms to coordinate the actions of a large number of loads without a central decision-maker. Distributed (as opposed to centralized) control will be necessary since the communication and computation burden of a centralized scheme is overwhelming. At the same time, distributed control algorithms need to deliver reliable performance with low communication bandwidth, and be cognizant of the privacy and security concerns inherent in such Cyber Physical Systems (CPS) with humans in the loop. The second challenge is that the demand manipulation at the loads has to be done in such a manner that consumers. Quality of Service (QoS) is maintained in tight, pre-negotiated bounds. A number of technical innovations undergird the proposed work. These innovations include (1) frequency decomposition to map consumer resources to grid?s needs, (2) randomized control algorithms to convert intractable combinatorial optimization problems to tractable convex problems, and (3) physical signaling through grid-frequency and voltage measurements to enable multi-agent coordination without explicit communication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The future electric grid will use a much larger fraction of green energy, especially solar and wind, than it does now. Solar and wind are however intermittent, and thus energy storage is on everyone's mind. The goal of the project is to help the electric grid remain highly reliable even when a large fraction of the electric energy comes from intermittent sources, without having to rely solely on large expensive batteries. Instead of investing in batteries, this project seeks to obtain cheap storage by manipulating power demand in consumer loads through intelligent decision-making algorithms.


By varying power demand up and down from what an electric load ? such as an air conditioner - would nominally consume, the load can be made to behave like a battery, effectively creating a source of Virtual Energy Storage (VES). The trick is to make sure consumers? quality of service is not affected, so that no one even notices that their electric loads are constantly making tiny adjustments. Doing so is possible since most electric loads such as air conditioning systems have tremendous amount of flexibility in how and when they consume power (measured in kW). The consumer only cares about the service (comfortable indoors) and how much energy they consume in a month (utility bill). But not at what instant how many kW of power they draw from the grid.

 

The project's goal is to develop methods to coordinate a large number of loads to obtain a large amount of virtual energy storage. Because the only change is a software and no new equipment is needed, the cost of virtual energy storage is a lot lower than batteries.

 

As part of the project, we made a number of contributions:

 

1. Research: We developed algorithms to coordinate millions of consumer and industrial loads to act like batteries. The performance and effectiveness of these algorithms were established through analysis, high-fidelity digital simulations, and in some cases, experiments on real buildings. Coordinating large number of loads to help the grid while ensuring that no load has to violate its own quality of service has been a bottleneck in past research on demand flexibility. This project solved this problem by developing new mathematical techniques to break this complexity barrier. One of these mathematical techniques developed, which comes under the umbrella of "Artificial Intelligence" (specifically, Reinforcement Learning) is also useful to many other engineering problems, not just the power grid.

 

We also developed methods to estimate how much (virtual) energy storage a number of loads can provide. The methods we developed will help grid planners and operators answer questions like: "how many residential air conditioners are equivalent to a 3 MW/2 MWh Li-ion battery?". These methods are useful to the grid planners to decide on the best mix of resources: actual batteries and smart loads providing battery like service to get the right balance between cost and reliability.

 

Some of the methods we developed are beneficial not only to the power grid but also to the owners of the loads that provide virtual energy storage. This benefit comes from the ability of the methods to reduce the total energy consumption of the loads through intelligent control. This energy efficiency technology improves the nation's energy security and reduces emissions.

 

 

2) Education: Seven PhD students (and their dissertation work) were supported partially by this grant. The students and the PIs together co-authored a total of 42 research papers and dissertations based on this research. They disseminated the results to national and international audiences through journal articles and conference publications. Three of the graduate students involved in the research have joined U.S. National Laboratories such as National Renewable National Laboratory. The project has thus contributed to the training of the nation's STEM workforce.

 

3) Industry outreach: We also disseminated the research results to industry and many power grid operators in the U.S and the world, including North Eastern Independent System Operator, Florida Power and Light, and EDF (in Paris, France). EDF in particular is testing some of the methods we developed for widespread deployment.
